awd_titl_txt: Fundamentals of Quantum Materials Winter School and Workshop
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports the 2023 Fundamentals of Quantum Materials (FQM) Winter School and Workshop at the University of Maryland. This meeting is dedicated specifically to the synthesis, characterization and electronic modelling of quantum materials.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The Fundamentals of Quantum Materials Winter School is designed to provide top junior scientists with a pedagogical background and practical training in quantum materials research, with an instruction emphasis on a wide range of modern techniques of materials synthesis given by the top scientists in the US. The main program centers around a week-long school program with ~30-40 selected students/postdocs and ~10 invited speakers from around the US and Canada, with lectures in the mornings followed by practical sessions on materials synthesis in the afternoons. This has been a very successful format. The practical sessions make use of the extensive crystal growth facilities in the Maryland Quantum Materials Center, and cover topics including flux growth, arc melting, solid state synthesis and hydrothermal techniques, and a visit to the NIST Center for Neutron Scattering will likely be included again.  The school will again be followed by a day-long workshop hosting prominent QM researchers and focused on a current research topic following the theme of the school.

The 7th FQM school, the theme was “High Pressure Synthesis and Measurement”, and included a combination of fundamental materials synthesis instruction as well as lectures on experimental techniques and practices from an impressive list of invited speakers.

First, we brought together 14 distinguished lecturers with well-established reputations in materials synthesis and characterization techniques to conduct a series of one-hour lectures covering a diverse set of techniques. A wide range of topics were covered, including materials design considerations, various synthesis techniques, 2D materials and devices, as well as career advice.

Ryan Baumbach, UC Santa Cruz

Bianca Haberl, Oak Ridge National Lab

Adam Jaffe, Notre Dame

Jason Jeffries, Livermore

John Mitchell, Argonne National Lab

Warren Pickett, UC Davis

Sheng Ran, Washington U-St. Louis

Efrain Rodriguez, Maryland

Valentin Taufour, UC Davis

Stan Tozer, NHMFL

Weiwei Xie, Michigan

Hanno Zur Loye, U of South Carolina

Tim Strobel, Carnegie

Rus Hemley, U of Illinois 

Second, three afternoons were devoted to practical demonstrations of techniques at laboratories in the University of Maryland Physics and Chemistry departments.  These included six modules: 

  1. Floating Zone Growth
  2. Arc Melting Techniques
  3. Molten Metal Flux Growth
  4. Hydrothermal
  5. X-ray Diffraction Techniques
  6. Measurements

On the first day, the organizers hosted a poster session and dinner banquet attended by all participants and senior scientists, and included a diverse (and pleasingly high-quality) set of poster presentations.

On the fourth afternoon, school participants were bussed over to Gaithersburg, MD for a tour of the NIST Center for Neutron Scattering, introducing them to aspects of neutron scattering routinely used in sample characterization and quantum materials research in general. 

The fifth day centered on a day-long workshop (Jan 19, at The Hotel), which brought together about 60 presenters and participants to discuss a variety of topics focused on the central theme “High Pressure Synthesis and Measurement”. The main goal was to bring together a focused group from the physics, chemistry and materials science communities to showcase current and developing research pursuits in quantum materials research. The event was well attended and included several lively discussions about research presented during the day. The coffee breaks, lunch and dinner periods all brought together school students and invited lecturers and speakers in a very interactive atmosphere that produced very positive feedback
